blog.[id].js: // Page to view a single blog post

components.Post.js: // Component to display a blog post

__dict__.master_design_description: The project is structured to separate concerns effectively. The 'app' directory contains the main application pages, including the homepage, blog, and authentication pages. The 'components' directory holds reusable UI components like Header, Footer, and Post. The 'lib' directory is for utility functions, such as authentication helpers. The 'pages/api' directory is used for API routes, including NextAuth.js configuration for handling authentication. The 'styles' directory contains global styles, and the 'public' directory is for static assets like images. This structure follows Next.js best practices for scalability and maintainability.

blog.index.js: // Page to list all blog posts
blog.[id].js: // Page to view a single blog post

__dict__.my_func_des: The 'app' directory is responsible for managing the main application pages, which include the homepage, blog, and authentication pages. It serves as the core structure for rendering the primary views of the application, ensuring that users can navigate through the main sections of the site.
list_sub_func_des: The 'homepage' subdirectory contains the 'page.js' file, which is a Next.js page component responsible for rendering the homepage of the application.
The 'blog' subdirectory includes 'index.js' for listing all blog posts and '[id].js' for viewing individual blog posts, providing a structure for blog content management.
The 'auth' subdirectory consists of 'signin.js' and 'signout.js', which handle the sign-in and sign-out functionalities, respectively, facilitating user authentication processes.
